In situs endoscopic surgery, debridement was performed and the specimens were sent to pathology. A nasal biopsy showed wide hyphae without septa as shown in the given slide. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mucor. This patient is a diabetic male, recently treated with corticosteroids for severe COVID-19, presenting with facial and orbital swelling and nasal obstruction — a classic clinical picture of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. The key pathological clue is the nasal biopsy showing broad, non-septate (aseptate) hyphae with right-angle branching, which is characteristic of Mucor species. Mucormycosis is an aggressive, life-threatening fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, especially in immunocompromised individuals like diabetics and those receiving steroids. Incorrect Options: A. Candida Candida species are yeasts, not molds. On histology, they show budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae, not broad aseptate hyphae. C. Aspergillosis Aspergillus species form thin, septate hyphae with acute angle (45°) branching, which is different from the broad, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae of Mucor. D. (Blank) There is no fourth option provided, but if there were another fungal option, it still would not match the classical features of Mucor seen both clinically and histologically.

questions.text: 60 yr old patient with a recurrent nasal lesion as shown in the image, choose the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) The image depicts a lesion over the nasal region showing: A pearly, rolled border Central ulceration Telangiectatic vessels (visible blood vessels) on the surface These are classic features of Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) — the most common type of skin cancer, especially on sun-exposed areas like the face and nose. Typical patient profile Elderly (often >50 years) Fair-skinned History of chronic sun exposure Lesion often starts as a pearly nodule and can ulcerate (hence the term “rodent ulcer”) Slow-growing and locally invasive, but rarely metastasizes The recurrent nature and the classic appearance seen in the image strongly support the diagnosis of BCC. Incorrect Options: Option A: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) SCC is more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as: A scaly, ulcerated lesion Crusting or bleeding Faster growing More common on the lower lip, ears, and scalp Although it can occur on the nose, the lack of keratinization and crusting, along with the pearly rolled edge, makes SCC less likely here. Option C: Malignant Melanoma Melanoma presents as Pigmented lesions Asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter >6 mm, and evolving appearance (ABCDE rule) This lesion lacks pigmentation, and the described features don’t match a melanoma. Option D: Inverted Papilloma Inverted papillomas arise in the nasal cavity, typically present with: Nasal obstruction Possible epistaxis Often seen on imaging inside nasal passage They do not appear externally as ulcerated lesions and would not look like the one shown in the image.

questions.text: A 65 year old man came for the check up in OPD and on assessment he was only able to hear louder sounds like shouts and amplified sound. What is the grade of hearing loss you group into ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Severe hearing loss >70%. In hearing assessment, the degree of hearing loss is determined based on how loud a sound must be before it is heard. A person with severe hearing loss can only hear very loud sounds such as shouting or amplified speech. This corresponds to a hearing threshold of 70–90 dB HL, which often affects the ability to understand even amplified or loud conversational speech. Since the patient in this case can only hear loud shouts and amplified sounds, it falls within the severe hearing loss category. Incorrect Options: A. Profound <40% This is incorrect both in definition and percentage range. Profound hearing loss typically refers to thresholds above 90 dB HL, and patients may not hear even loud sounds. The percentage mentioned (“<40%”) is also inaccurate in this context. C. Moderately severe hearing loss <70% Moderately severe hearing loss falls in the 55–70 dB HL range. While this may cause difficulty in hearing normal conversation, people in this category can typically still hear loud speech without amplification. D. Moderate <50% Moderate hearing loss (41–55 dB HL) means difficulty hearing normal conversation, especially in noisy environments. These individuals can usually hear raised voices without the need for shouting.

questions.text: 45 yrs old male presents with sudden onset vertigo with moderate sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. Study the audiometry finding given below and choose the most appropraite diagosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer: (A) Meniere's Disease The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shown in the image reveals: Unilateral low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss Greater hearing loss in low frequencies (125–500 Hz) and relatively better thresholds at higher frequencies Clinical history includes sudden vertigo, tinnitus, and moderate hearing loss This pattern is classic for Meniere's Disease, a condition characterized by: Episodic vertigo Sensorineural hearing loss (typically fluctuating) Tinnitus Aural fullness Hearing loss in early stages typically affects low frequencies, as shown in the PTA. Incorrect Options: Option B: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) BPPV causes positional vertigo without hearing loss or tinnitus. Audiometry in BPPV is typically normal. Not consistent with the sensorineural hearing loss seen here. Option C: Acoustic Neuroma Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes imbalance, but not typically sudden vertigo. Hearing loss tends to be progressive, and initially high-frequency is affected — opposite of the pattern in this case. Option D: Labyrinthitis Labyrinthitis can cause sudden vertigo and hearing loss, similar to Meniere’s. However, the hearing loss is typically flat or high-frequency, not predominantly low-frequency. Also, labyrinthitis is usually post-viral or follows an upper respiratory infection, which is not mentioned here.

questions.text: What type of joint is arrow marked in this image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Saddle Joint The image shows the incudomalleolar joint in the middle ear, specifically between the malleus (handle of the mallet-shaped bone) and the incus (anvil-shaped bone). The arrow is pointing at the articulation between these two ossicles. This is a saddle-type synovial joint, which allows a limited gliding motion—essential for the efficient transmission of sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear. Key Characteristics of the Saddle Joint (as seen here): Each articulating surface is concave in one direction and convex in the other (like a rider on a saddle). Allows movement in two planes (biaxial): flexion-extension and abduction-adduction (in this case, specialized for vibration transmission). Found in areas needing precise but limited motion (e.g., thumb's carpometacarpal joint and ossicular joints). Incorrect Options: Option A: Pivot Joint Allows rotational movement (e.g., atlantoaxial joint between C1 and C2 vertebrae). Not relevant to the ossicular chain. Option B: Ball and Socket Joint Permits multiaxial movement (e.g., hip and shoulder joints). The ossicles do not have a spherical articulating surface and do not require such a wide range of motion. Option D: Fibrous Joint These are immovable joints held together by fibrous tissue (e.g., sutures of the skull). The middle ear ossicles are mobile and form synovial joints, not fibrous ones.

questions.text: Choose the most appropraite sttement regarding sensory cells of inner ear 1. Inner hair cells and outer hair cells present in the ratio of 1:3 2. Inner hair cells are only responsible to transmit auditory impulses. 3. Outer hair cells are responsible for tectorial membrane movement. 4. Inner Hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory inpulses.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1 and 4. The sensory cells of the inner ear include inner hair cells (IHCs) and outer hair cells (OHCs), which play distinct roles in the process of hearing. Statement 1 is correct: Inner and outer hair cells are present in a ratio of approximately 1:3, meaning there are about three outer hair cells for every inner hair cell. Statement 4 is correct: Inner hair cells are arranged in a single row along the cochlear spiral and are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory impulses to the brain via the auditory nerve. They convert mechanical energy into electrical signals. These two statements are accurate, making Option C the correct choice. Incorrect Options: Statement 2: "Inner hair cells are only responsible to transmit auditory impulses." This is misleading. While inner hair cells do transmit auditory signals, outer hair cells also contribute to the cochlear amplifier mechanism, which indirectly enhances auditory signal detection. The word “only” makes the statement overly exclusive. Statement 3: "Outer hair cells are responsible for tectorial membrane movement." This is inaccurate. Outer hair cells contribute to cochlear amplification by changing their length in response to sound (electromotility), which affects the basilar membrane, not directly the tectorial membrane. The tectorial membrane is a gelatinous structure that interacts with hair cell stereocilia but is not actively moved by the OHCs.

questions.text: 30 yrs old pregnant female complaining of hearing loss was operated as shown in the image, choose the most appropriate surgical procedure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stapedotomy The image shows a middle ear surgery where a prosthesis is placed replacing the stapes (the third ossicle), indicating a stapedotomy procedure. This surgery is typically performed for otosclerosis, a condition common in young females (especially worsens during pregnancy) and causes conductive hearing loss due to fixation of the stapes footplate. In stapedotomy: A small hole is made in the fixed stapes footplate. A prosthesis is inserted to transmit sound from the incus to the inner ear (oval window), bypassing the fixed stapes. Clinical Clues Matching the Diagnosis: Young female (30 years old) Pregnancy-associated hearing loss (common trigger for otosclerosis worsening) Prosthesis involving the stapes in the image Incorrect Options: Option A: Tympanoplasty Aims to reconstruct the tympanic membrane and/or ossicles. Does not typically involve a stapes prosthesis. Done for chronic otitis media or tympanic membrane perforation. Option B: Myringoplasty A type of tympanoplasty limited to repairing the tympanic membrane only. No ossicular chain work is done, and no prosthesis is placed. Option D: Ossiculoplasty Involves repair or reconstruction of ossicles, often using prostheses. May resemble the image, but stapedotomy is more specific, especially in otosclerosis with a fixed stapes footplate, as shown here.

choices.text: Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane
Malleus Incus disruption with tympanic membrane perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following will have the maximum hearing loss?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membraneOssicular discontinuity (especially involving the incudostapedial or incudomalleolar joints) results in maximum conductive hearing loss — often up to 40–60 dB.The tympanic membrane may still appear intact, but if the ossicular chain is disrupted, sound transmission from the TM to the cochlea is severely compromised.Among all the listed conditions, this results in the greatest mechanical disruption of the sound pathway.Incorrect Options:B. Malleus-Incus disruption with tympanic membrane perforationWhile this involves both ossicular disruption and TM perforation, the combined loss is not necessarily greater than complete ossicular discontinuity with an intact membrane, as some sound may still transmit via bone conduction or residual membrane.C. Otitis Media with EffusionThis causes mild to moderate conductive hearing loss (20–35 dB) due to fluid in the middle ear, which dampens the movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicles, but does not completely block sound transmission.D. Partial fixation of stapesThis refers to early otosclerosis, which may cause progressive conductive hearing loss, but the loss is typically less than that caused by complete ossicular discontinuity.

questions.text: Identfy the fracture
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chevallet Fracture The image depicts a sagittal section of the nasal cavity showing a fracture through the cartilaginous part of the nasal septum, particularly the septal cartilage — which is characteristic of a Chevallet fracture. Chevallet fracture refers to a fracture of the nasal septal cartilage, especially in its anterior portion. Commonly results from direct trauma to the nasal tip. It typically does not involve bony components and is limited to cartilage. Can cause nasal deformity, septal hematoma, or obstruction. Incorrect Options: Option B: Jarjavay Fracture Involves vertical fracture of the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid and adjacent septal structures. More posterior and involves bony septum, unlike the cartilage-only Chevallet fracture. Option C: Le Fort I Fracture A horizontal fracture of the maxilla above the level of the teeth. Involves maxillary bone and hard palate, not just the nasal septum. Extends from the nasal septum through the maxillary sinuses to the pterygoid plates. Option D: Le Fort II Fracture A pyramidal fracture involving: Nasal bridge Maxilla Lacrimal bones Orbital floor More extensive and involves multiple facial bones, not isolated to the septal cartilage.

questions.text: Audiogram shown in the image is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mixed Hearing Loss The audiogram shown displays A gap between air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) thresholds Both AC and BC thresholds are elevated (i.e., worse than normal hearing) Air-bone gap is present (black double arrow) This pattern is characteristic of Mixed Hearing Loss, which includes: A sensorineural component (elevated BC thresholds) A conductive component (elevated AC thresholds with preserved air-bone gap) How to Interpret Audiogram Symbols: Bone conduction: Usually marked by symbols like [ and ], or sometimes just lines at lower threshold Air conduction: Marked by X (left ear) and O (right ear) In mixed hearing loss: both sets are shifted upward (indicating hearing loss) but with a gap between them Incorrect Options: Option A: Noise-Induced Trauma This typically shows a "noise notch" at 4,000 Hz in bone conduction (sensorineural). No air-bone gap — so it’s a pure sensorineural hearing loss, not mixed. Option B: Conductive Hearing Loss In pure conductive loss, bone conduction is normal, and only air conduction is elevated, with a clear air-bone gap. Here, both AC and BC are raised, so it’s not purely conductive. Option D: Sensorineural Deafness Both AC and BC are equally elevated, and no air-bone gap is present. In this case, the air-bone gap indicates a conductive component, ruling out pure SNHL.

questions.text: Which of the following condition will have very poor prognosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)Bilateral Complete Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Palsy (RLNP)Bilateral Complete RLNP is the most serious and life-threatening condition among the options. It results in:Complete paralysis of both vocal cords, usually in a paramedian or midline position.This severely narrows the airway and can lead to:StridorSevere airway obstructionRespiratory distressPatients often require a tracheostomy to secure the airway, and voice is also compromised due to immobile cords. Prognosis is poor because:Both breathing and phonation are affected.Recovery of bilateral nerve function is rare.Surgical correction (e.g., cordotomy or arytenoidectomy) has limited voice outcomes.Incorrect Options:A. Unilateral Partial RLNPGenerally mild. One vocal cord has reduced movement but the airway remains adequate. Compensation by the opposite cord often preserves phonation and breathing. Good prognosis.B. Unilateral Complete RLNPMore serious than partial, but still tolerable. One cord is immobile, but the contralateral side may compensate. Patients may have hoarseness but usually no airway compromise.C. Bilateral Partial RLNPLess severe than bilateral complete. There may be some cord movement, and though airway compromise can occur, it is usually less severe than with complete bilateral palsy. Tracheostomy may be delayed or avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common organism of CROUP ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer: C. Influenza virus Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is a common respiratory illness in children, characterized by: Barking cough Stridor Hoarseness Inspiratory breathing difficulty It primarily affects the subglottic region of the airway and is viral in origin. The most common causative organisms include: Parainfluenza virus (Types 1, 2, 3) — most common overall Influenza A and B viruses — also important causes RSV, Adenovirus, Rhinovirus — less commonly Hence, Influenza virus is one of the most common viral causes, especially in seasonal outbreaks, and its inclusion here reflects that. Note: Parainfluenza virus type 1 is the most common cause overall, but since it's not listed in the options, Influenza virus is the best correct answer among those given. Incorrect Options: A. Haemophilus influenzae This is a bacterial organism, previously a common cause of epiglottitis, not croup. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae Typically causes pneumonia, otitis media, and sinusitis—not croup. D. Diphtheria Causes pseudomembranous pharyngitis and airway obstruction, but it is not a cause of classic viral croup.

questions.text: Which of the following test is used as screening procedure in newborn?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions)Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) is the preferred screening test for newborn hearing because:It is quick, non-invasive, and portableIt does not require active cooperation from the infantDetects outer hair cell function in the cochleaOAE is widely used as the first-line screening tool in Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) programs. A “refer” result may then be followed up with BERA for confirmation.Incorrect Options:B. BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry)BERA is more definitive and diagnostic, and used when OAE is abnormal. However, it is not the first-line screening test due to longer duration, cost, and the need for a quiet or sedated infant.C. PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry)Requires active patient participation—only suitable for children >5 years old or cooperative older children/adults. Not usable for newborns.D. Hand and ClapA crude, outdated method—subjective and unreliable for assessing hearing in newborns. Not acceptable in modern clinical practice.

questions.text: Audiogram shown in the image is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Otosclerosis The audiogram shows Air-bone gap (i.e., air conduction [AC] is worse than bone conduction [BC]) → indicating conductive hearing loss A dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz → this is the Carhart’s notch, a classic sign of otosclerosis Key Feature – Carhart’s Notch: A specific depression in bone conduction threshold at 2000 Hz Caused not by true sensorineural damage, but by mechanical changes in the ossicular chain (especially stapes fixation) Seen in otosclerosis, where abnormal bony remodeling of the otic capsule causes stapes footplate fixation Incorrect Options: Option A: Noise-Induced Trauma Shows a notch at 4000 Hz in both AC and BC (sensorineural pattern), not an air-bone gap No Carhart’s notch Option B: Meniere’s Disease Typically shows low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss BC and AC both affected, but no air-bone gap or Carhart’s notch Option D: Sensorineural Deafness BC and AC both reduced with no air-bone gap This audiogram clearly shows conductive hearing loss, ruling this out

choices.text: B/I rinne positive Weber lateralised to right
B/I rinne negative Weber lateralised to right
B/I rinne positive Weber lateralised to left
B/I rinne negative Weber lateralised to left

questions.text: A woman was has hearing loss In right ear and she was offered right ear stapedotomy. What is the Rinne and Weber's finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)Bilateral Rinne negative, Weber lateralized to rightThis case describes a woman with hearing loss in the right ear and she is being offered a right ear stapedotomy, which is a classic treatment for otosclerosis.Otosclerosis is a conductive hearing loss caused by fixation of the stapes footplate at the oval window. It typically affects young to middle-aged women and often begins unilaterally before becoming bilateral.Tuning Fork Test Findings in Conductive Hearing Loss:Rinne TestNegative on the affected side: Bone conduction > air conduction (abnormal)In bilateral otosclerosis, both ears may show Rinne negativeWeber TestIn conductive hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the affected sideSo, if the right ear has conductive loss ? Weber lateralizes to rightIncorrect Options:A. Bilateral Rinne positive, Weber to rightRinne would not be positive in a patient with conductive loss (it would be negative on the affected side).C. Bilateral Rinne positive, Weber to leftBoth components are incorrect: Rinne should be negative in affected ear, and Weber should lateralize to right, not left.D. Bilateral Rinne negative, Weber to leftWeber should lateralize to the right (affected ear), not the left.

questions.text: A South Indian male cattle breeder comes with complaints of frank intermittent epistaxis. The examination of the nose is given below. A biopsy was taken and HPE appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)RhinosporidiosisRhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an aquatic protist organism. It is endemic in parts of South India and Sri Lanka, especially among people exposed to pond or stagnant water, like cattle breeders.Typical clinical features:Recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds)Nasal obstructionA reddish, polypoidal mass in the nasal cavity, often friable and bleeds on touchOften multiple grape-like or strawberry-like massesHistopathology (HPE):Shows large sporangia containing numerous endosporesSurrounded by granulomatous inflammationIncorrect Options:A. Nasal polypUsually pale, non-bleeding, edematous masses. No history of bleeding or characteristic sporangia on HPE.C. HemangiomaVascular tumor; may cause bleeding but lacks sporangia. HPE would show blood-filled vascular channels, not spores.D. RhinophymaChronic form of rosacea affecting the nose. Presents as bulbous thickening of nasal skin, not intranasal mass or epistaxis.

questions.text: Comment on the block shown in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Naso-Ciliary Block The image shows a needle being inserted near the root of the nose, along the medial aspect of the orbit — this is the site for a naso-ciliary nerve block, a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve. The naso-ciliary nerve supplies: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal nerves The external nasal branch Sensation to the anterior septum, anterior ethmoid sinus, nasal dorsum, and part of the cornea Uses of Naso-Ciliary Block: Nasal surgeries (septoplasty, ethmoidectomy) Reduction of nasal pain As part of regional anesthesia for endoscopic sinus surgery Incorrect Options: Option A: Infra-Trochlear Block Targets the medial canthus area to block sensation to the medial eyelids and bridge of nose The site is more superficial and medial, closer to the trochlea of the superior oblique muscle Option C: Sphenopalatine Block Done deep in the posterior nasal cavity, typically via transnasal approach Not done externally or at the dorsum of the nose Option D: Inferior Orbital Block Given below the infraorbital rim, to anesthetize infraorbital nerve (V2 branch) Provides sensation to lower eyelid, upper lip, cheek The site is much more inferior to the injection shown

questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. 1b 2c 3d 4a The correct matching is based on anatomical proximity and pathophysiological effects of thyroid swelling on surrounding structures. A thyroid mass may compress or infiltrate nearby organs and nerves, leading to characteristic symptoms. Esophagus (1) ? Dysphagia (b): The esophagus lies posterior to the thyroid gland. Enlargement of the thyroid can press on the esophagus, leading to difficulty in swallowing. Trachea (2) ? Dyspnea (c): The trachea is anterior to the esophagus and often displaced or compressed by a large goiter, leading to respiratory difficulty. Sympathetic Chain (3) ? Horner Syndrome (d): Compression of the cervical sympathetic chain causes Horner syndrome, which includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (4) ? Hoarseness (a): This nerve runs in the tracheoesophageal groove and supplies intrinsic muscles of the larynx. Compression results in hoarseness due to vocal cord paralysis. Incorrect Options: Option B: 1c 2b 3d 4a This mismatches esophagus with dyspnea and trachea with dysphagia, which is anatomically incorrect. The esophagus is a digestive structure and compression causes swallowing difficulty (dysphagia), not breathing difficulty (dyspnea). The trachea, when compressed, causes dyspnea—not dysphagia. Option C: 1b 2c 3a 4d Incorrectly matches sympathetic chain with hoarseness and recurrent laryngeal nerve with Horner syndrome. This is a clear anatomical mismatch. The recurrent laryngeal nerve affects voice (hoarseness), not the sympathetic chain. The sympathetic chain involvement causes Horner syndrome, not voice change. Option D: 1b 2d 3c 4a Here, trachea is incorrectly matched with Horner syndrome, and sympathetic chain with dyspnea, which are not accurate. The trachea causes dyspnea when compressed, and the sympathetic chain—located more laterally—leads to Horner syndrome when affected.

questions.text: A girl is having difficult to understand speech and language problems complaining of hearing loss but when assessed she can hear voice and her PTA results are deferred fro OAE which is positive. BERA/CERA shows loss of cortical spike and medial geniculate spike. Which of the fonowing is most probable Diagnosis;
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)Auditory NeuropathyAuditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD) is a hearing disorder in which outer hair cell function in the cochlea is normal, but there is disruption in the transmission of sound signals from the inner ear to the brain.This condition is characterized by:Normal OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions) – indicating intact outer hair cells.Abnormal or absent BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) / CERA (Cortical Evoked Response Audiometry) – suggesting neural desynchrony.Speech perception difficulties – the patient can hear sounds but has trouble understanding speech.Medial geniculate body and cortical response loss – points to post-synaptic neural pathway involvement.These findings together are classic for auditory neuropathy, especially when there is a mismatch between peripheral hearing test results (normal OAE) and central processing tests (abnormal BERA/CERA).Incorrect Options:B. MalingeringIn malingering, test results are inconsistent, but objective tests like BERA and OAE typically show normal findings. Here, objective testing shows abnormal auditory pathway beyond the cochlea, making malingering unlikely.C. Michel AplasiaA complete absence of inner ear structures (congenital), which would result in absent OAE and BERA. But in this case, OAE is present, so Michel aplasia is ruled out.D. Cochlear otosclerosisThis involves fixation of the stapes and leads to conductive hearing loss, often with abnormal PTA and absent OAE, not the pattern seen here. BERA may be relatively preserved if the cochlea and nerve are intact.

questions.text: Arrange the auditory pathway in order from periphery to centre A. Eight nerve B.Inferior colliculus C. Medial geniculate body D. Ventral / dorsal cochlear nucleus E. Superior Olivary nucleus F. Lateral lemniscus G. Auditory cortex
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)a, d, e, f, b, c, gThe auditory pathway is a complex ascending pathway that transmits sound from the periphery (ear) to the auditory cortex in the brain. Here's the correct order from peripheral to central structures:Step-by-step Pathway:A. Auditory (8th cranial) nerve –Transmits electrical signals from the cochlea to the brainstem.D. Ventral and dorsal cochlear nucleus –Located at the pontomedullary junction, where the auditory nerve first synapses.E. Superior olivary nucleus –Receives bilateral input and is important for sound localization.F. Lateral lemniscus –Major ascending tract for auditory information from the brainstem to midbrain.B. Inferior colliculus –A midbrain nucleus that integrates auditory information.C. Medial geniculate body –Part of the thalamus, it acts as the relay station to the cortex.G. Auditory cortex (in temporal lobe) –Final destination where sound is consciously perceived.? Final Order:A. a ? d ? e ? f ? b ? c ? gIncorrect Options:B, C, D – These options either misplace the sequence, skip key steps, or start from central structures, which is incorrect in a peripheral-to-central arrangement.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of aforeign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On examination, a reddish pedunculated mass studded with whitish spots was seen hanging in nasal cavity. On nasal endoscopy, mass was seen attached along the under surface of left inferior turbinate, which bled on contact. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. After a clinical diagnosis of rhinosporidisis, he underwent complete excision of the mass after ipolar cauterisation of the base under local anaesthesis.Postoperative histopathology revealed multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation with dense inflammation.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rhinosporidiosis Explanation of Correct Answer: The clinical and histopathological findings are classical for Rhinosporidiosis, a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Key Diagnostic Clues in the Case: Presentation: Nasal mass with recurrent epistaxis and foreign body sensation Exposure: History of bathing in stagnant pond water (a known source of infection) Appearance: Reddish, vascular pedunculated mass with white spots (mature sporangia) Bleeds on touch: Common in rhinosporidial lesions Histology: Large thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores in various stages of development Management: Complete surgical excision with cauterization of base to prevent recurrence Incorrect Options: Option A: Rhinoscleroma Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis Chronic, slowly progressive infection of nose and upper airway Histology shows Mikulicz cells (foamy macrophages), not sporangia Not associated with white dots or pond exposure Option C: Angiofibroma Seen in adolescent males Highly vascular tumor presenting with profuse epistaxis Usually arises from sphenopalatine foramen, not inferior turbinate No sporangia seen on histology Option D: Nasal Polyp Soft, painless, edematous mucosal outgrowth Associated with allergies, asthma Does not bleed easily on touch No white spots or sporangia

questions.text: Study the given slide and comment where the given structure drains:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sphenoethmoidal Recess The image shows a dissected coronal section of the nasal cavity, highlighting the sphenoid sinus (circled in blue). The sphenoid sinus drains into a specific region called the sphenoethmoidal recess. The sphenoethmoidal recess is located above and posterior to the superior turbinate. It serves as the drainage site for the sphenoid sinus, which lies posteriorly in the skull base. Incorrect Options: Option A: Inferior Meatus Lies below the inferior turbinate Receives drainage from the nasolacrimal duct, not the sphenoid sinus Option B: Middle Meatus Located beneath the middle turbinate Drains the frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoidal air cells Sphenoid sinus does not drain here Option C: Superior Meatus Lies below the superior turbinate Receives drainage from the posterior ethmoidal air cells, but not the sphenoid sinus

questions.text: 50 yrs old female complaining of foreign body sensation, change in voice with a history of eating fish. On examination there was a fish bone in the pyriform fossa (pyriform fossa was inflamed). Choose the nerve responsible
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (ISLN) is responsible for sensory innervation of the mucosa of the larynx above the vocal cords, including the pyriform fossa, laryngeal inlet, and posterior surface of the epiglottis. When a foreign body like a fish bone gets lodged in the pyriform fossa, it stimulates this nerve, causing a foreign body sensation, discomfort, and sometimes referred pain or coughing. Incorrect Options: a. Recurrent laryngeal nerve – This nerve provides motor innervation to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except cricothyroid) and sensory innervation below the vocal cords, not the pyriform fossa. c. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve – It supplies motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle (which tenses the vocal cords), but does not have a sensory role in the mucosa. d. Glossopharyngeal nerve – This nerve provides sensory innervation to the oropharynx, posterior third of the tongue, and tonsillar region, not the pyriform fossa, which is part of the hypopharynx.

questions.text: A 7 yrs old child with a history of ear infection complaining of lock jaw and limbs spasm/fever/neck rigidity. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bezold abscess Bezold abscess is a deep neck abscess that arises as a complication of mastoiditis (which itself follows an ear infection). It occurs when pus from mastoid air cells erodes through the medial aspect of the mastoid tip into the sternocleidomastoid muscle, leading to: • Neck rigidity • Trismus (lockjaw) due to irritation/inflammation of adjacent muscles • Fever and systemic toxicity • Neck swelling and tenderness It typically affects children and adolescents, especially with a delayed or poorly treated otitis media. Incorrect Options: a. Meningitis – Can cause fever and neck rigidity, but trismus and limb spasms are not typical. Also, the link to ear infection more strongly suggests a local complication rather than a generalized CNS infection. b. Tetany – Caused by hypocalcemia, leading to muscle spasms, but does not present with fever or ear infection history. Also, lockjaw is not a defining feature of tetany. d. Sinus thrombosis – May occur post-otitis media or mastoiditis (esp. lateral sinus thrombosis), but more often presents with headache, papilledema, and neurological symptoms, not primarily trismus and neck rigidity.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Biopsy because it is a procedure that is contraindicated for this condition. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is a highly vascular tumor that is fed by blood vessels, primarily from the external carotid artery. Due to this characteristic, attempting a biopsy can trigger a massive, life-threatening hemorrhage. Therefore, a biopsy is not part of the diagnostic process. The diagnosis is instead made based on the clinical presentation (e.g., recurrent nosebleeds in an adolescent boy) and confirmed through imaging studies like CT and MRI, which reveal the tumor's location and extent without the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: A 50 yrs old female compaling episode of acute vertigo with vomiting unsteadiness and light-headedness, which was triggered by changing her head position in morning. She denied hearing loss, recent viral illness, medication use, head injury or trauma. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) BPPV Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) is the most common cause of positional vertigo, characterized by: • Brief episodes of vertigo lasting seconds to minutes • Triggered by specific head movements (e.g., turning in bed, looking up/down) • Associated with nausea, vomiting, and unsteadiness • No hearing loss or neurologic symptoms • Often idiopathic, especially in older adults It occurs due to dislodged otoliths (calcium carbonate crystals) moving into the semicircular canals, most commonly the posterior canal, disturbing endolymph flow during head movement. Incorrect Options: a. Meniere disease – Causes episodic vertigo, but usually with hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness, which are absent here. c. Vestibular neuritis – Presents with acute, prolonged vertigo lasting days, often following a viral illness, and not typically triggered by position changes. d. Acoustic neuroma – Typically causes progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes unsteadiness, but not acute vertigo triggered by head movement.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate candidates for Cochlear Implants 1. Ototoxicity 2. Congenital hearing loss 3. Ossicular fixation 4. Otosclerosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1 and 2 Cochlear implants are indicated in cases of sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) where the cochlear hair cells are damaged, but the auditory nerve is intact. The best candidates include: 1. Ototoxicity – Certain drugs (e.g., aminoglycosides) can damage cochlear hair cells, causing bilateral SNHL. These patients often benefit from cochlear implants. 2. Congenital hearing loss – Children born with bilateral profound SNHL are excellent candidates, especially when implanted early (before age 2) for optimal speech and language development. Incorrect Options: 3. Ossicular fixation – This is a conductive hearing loss, often due to otosclerosis or chronic otitis media, and is best treated with surgical correction (e.g., stapedectomy) or hearing aids, not cochlear implants. 4. Otosclerosis – Early stages affect the stapes (conductive loss); later stages (cochlear otosclerosis) may involve SNHL, but cochlear implantation is rarely the first line and reserved for severe cochlear involvement, which is uncommon.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnosis can cause stridor in infants 1. Laryngomalacia 2. Congenital Hemangioma V/S Polyp 3. Subglottic stenosis 4. Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stridor in infants is a high-pitched, noisy breathing sound typically due to upper airway obstruction. The following are common causes of stridor in infants: 1. Laryngomalacia – The most common cause of stridor in infants, due to floppy supraglottic structures collapsing during inspiration. It presents as inspiratory stridor soon after birth. 3. Subglottic stenosis – A narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, which may be congenital or acquired (post-intubation). It causes biphasic stridor and respiratory distress. 4. Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) – Caused by HPV types 6 and 11, it results in wart-like growths in the airway, especially the larynx, and leads to progressive stridor and hoarseness. Incorrect Option: 2. Congenital hemangioma/polyp – While congenital hemangioma (especially subglottic) can rarely cause stridor, polyps are extremely rare in infants and not a common cause of stridor. Hence, this option is not as consistent or reliable compared to the other three.
